publicationStmt.publisher: Published by the Open Publishing Unit of The Pennsylvania State University Libraries.

respStmt.name: Former Owner - Author of Handwritten Annotations

monogr.author: Francis Beaumont
John Fletcher
monogr.title: Comedies and Tragedies Written by Francis Beavmont and Iohn Fletcher, Gentlemen. Never printed before, And now published by the Authours Originall Copies.

imprint.pubPlace: The Prince Armes in St. Pauls Church-yard

encodingDesc.p: This document is a simplified "true-to-text" XML version of The Spanish Curate based on Pennsylvania State University's annotated copy of the 1647 Beaumont & Fletcher first folio. Major textual elements and attributes have been captured based on how they appear in the folio. Whenever possible, editorial interventions have been minimalized or avoided entirely. This document is meant to serve as a pedagogical tool by which students of Early Modern literature can learn to construct edited XML versions of the play.

projectDesc.p: The Digital Beaumont & Fletcher (1647) is a collaborative editorial project aimed at making many of the rarely edited—and, as a result, rarely taught—plays in the “Beaumont & Fletcher” canon accessible to student readers and freely available online for classroom use. This project was inspired by the distinctive copy of Comedies and Tragedies Written by Francis Beavmont And Iohn Fletcher Gentlemen (1647) held by Penn State University's Eberly Family Special Collections Library. In addition to preserving evidence of ownership dating to as early as 1703, Penn State's copy of this printed play collection also includes three plays with handwritten marginalia, suggesting that the book might have been used to facilitate performance in the late seventeenth century. This project is also motivated by a desire to make the texts and other features of this book more widely known and readable. As a first step, the whole volume has now been fully digitized, thanks to the department of Preservation, Conservation, and Digitization at Penn State Libraries.

editorialDecl.p: Provides details of editorial principles and practices applied during the encoding of a text

correction.p: This transcription copies almost exactly the text from Penn State's copy of the first folio. Moderniztions in certain letters were followed (I for J, VV for W, etc.) Obivous errors were corrected (upside down letters (n for a u, I for l, etc.). Manuscript notes are included in the transcription, placed as closely as possible to the original placement on the page. For further details about editoral principles, please consult the project website.

normalization.p: ALL words converted to Modern British spelling following Oxford English Dictionary.

punctuation.p: Punctuation was modernized to register full syntactical units.

handNote.p: This edition of The Spanish Curate contains the manuscript notes found in the Penn State Libraries' copy of the 1647 folio. These manuscript notes are particually attentive to the performance of the play, and prepare actors for entrances and emphasize stage directions throughout the text. For more information on these manuscript notes, consult the editorial principles and the introduction to The Spanish Curate.

lg.l: Heare but my reaſons,
O my patience heare 'em.
Can cunning falſhood colour an excuſe?
With any ſeeming ſhape of borrowed truth?
Extenuate this wofull wrong, not error.
You gave conſent that to defeat my brother
I ſhould take any courſe,
But not to make
The cure more loathſome then the fowle diſeaſe:
Was't not enough you took me to your bed,
Tir'd with looſe dalliance, and with emptie veines,
All thoſe abilities ſpent before and waſted,
That could conferre the name of mother on me?
But that (to perfect my account of ſorrow)
For my long barreneſſe you muſt highten it
By ſhewing to my face, that you were fruitfull
Hug'd in the baſe embraces of another?
If Solitude that dwelt beneath my roofe,
And want of children was a torment to me
What end my vexation to behold
A baſtard to upbraid me with my wants?
And heare the name of father paid to ye
Yet know my ſelf no mother,
What can I ſay?
ſhall I confeſse my fault and aſk your pardon?
Will that content ye?
If it could make void,
What is confirm'd in Court, No, no, Don Henrique,
You ſhall know that I find my ſelf abus'd,
And adde to that I have a woman's anger.
And while I look upon this Baſilisk,
Whoſe envious eyes hath blaſted all my comforts
Reſt confident I'le ſtudy my dark ends,
And not your pleaſures,
Noble Lady, heare me,
Not my Fathers ſon, but as your ſervant,
Vouchſafe to heare me, for ſuch in my duty,
I ever will appeare: And far be it from
My poore ambition, ever to looke on you,
But with that reverence; which a ſlave ſtands bound
To pay a worthy Miſtris: I have heard
That Dames of higheſt place, nay Queenes themſelves,
Diſdaine not to be ſerv'd by ſuch as are
Of meaneſt Birth: and I ſhall be moſt happie,
To be emploi'd when you pleaſe to command me
Even in the courſest Office, as your Page,
I can wayte on your trencher: : fill your wine
Carry your pontafles, and be ſometimes bleſs'd
In all humilitie to touch your feete
Or if that you eſteeme that too much grace
I can run by your Coach: obſerve your lookes
And hope to gaine a fortune by my ſervice,
With your good favour, which now, as a Son,
I dare not challenge
As a Son,
Forgive me
I will forget the name, let it be death
For me to call you Mother.
Still upbraided?
No way left to appeaſe you?
None: now heare me:
Heare what I vow before the face of heaven,
And if I breake it all plagues in this life,
And thoſe that after death are fear'd, fall on me
While that this Baſtard ſtaies under my rooffe,
Looke for no peace at home, for I renounce
All Offices of a wife,
What am I falne to?
(howers
I will not eate, nor ſleepe with you and thoſe
Which I ſhould ſpend in prayers for your health
Shall be emploi'd in Curſes,
Terrible,
All the day long, i'le be as tedious to you
As lingring fevers, and i'le watch the nights,
To ring alou'd your ſhame, and breake your ſleepes
Or if you doe but ſlumber, i'le appeare
In the ſhape of all my wrongs, and like a fury
Fright you to madnes, and if all this faile
To worke out my revenge, I have friends and kinſmen,
That will not ſit downe tame with the diſgrace
That's offer'd to our noble familie
In what I ſuffer,
How am I devided
Betweene the duties I owe as a Huſband,
And pietie of a Parent?
I am taught Sir
By the inſtinct of nature that obedience
Which bids me to prefer your peace of mind,
Before thoſe pleaſures that are deareſt to me
Be wholy hers (my Lord) I quit all parts,
That I may challenge: may you grow old together
And no diſtaſt e're find you and before
The Characters of age are printed on you
May you ſee many Images of your ſelves,
Though I, like ſome falſe Glaſse, that's never look'd in
Am caſt a ſide, and broken from this hower
(Unles invited, which I dare not hope for)
I never will ſet my forbidden feete,
Over your threſhold: onely give me leave
Though caſt off to the world, to mention you,
In my devotions 'tis all I ſue for
And so I take my laſt leave
Though I am
Devoted to a wife nay allmoſt ſol'd
I ſlave to ſerve her pleaſures, yet I cannot
So part with all humanity, but I muſt
Shew something of a Father: thou ſhalt not goe
Unfurniſh'd and unfriended too: take that
To guard thee from neceſſities; may thy goodnes
Deſerve to be the heire of greater fortunes,
Then thou wer't borne to. Scorne me not Violante
This baniſhment is a kind of civill death,
And now, as it were at his Funerall
To ſhed a teare or two, one word more,
And ſo farewell for ever: one word more,
Though I muſt never see thee (my Aſcanio)
When this is ſpent (for so the Judge decreed)
Send to me for ſupply: are you pleas'd now?
Yes: I have cauſe: to ſee you howle and blubber
At the parting of my torment, & your ſhame Bed ready wine,
'Tis well, proceed; supply his wants: doe doe: table Standiſh &
Let the great dowre I brought serve to maintain Paper.
Your Baſtards riots: send my Clothes and Jewells,
To your old acquaintance, your deare dame his Mother
Now you begin to melt, I know 'twill follow,
Is all I doe miſconſtrude?
I will take
A courſe to right my ſelf a ſpeeding one:
By the bleſs'd Saints, I will; if I prove cruell
To ſhame to ſee thy fooliſh pitty, taught me
To looſe my natural ſoftneſs, keepe off from me
Thy flateries are infectious, and i'le fle thee
As I would doe a Leper.
Let not fury
Tranſport you ſo: you know I am your Creature.
All love, but to your ſelf, with him, hath left me
I'le ioyne with you in any thing
In vaine
I'le take mine owne waies, and will have no partners,
I will not croſſe you,
Doe not, they ſhall find
That to a Woman of her hopes beguil'd
A viper troad on, or an Aſpick's mild.
Sits the game there? I have you by mine order,
I love Leandro for't
But you muſt ſhew it
In lending him your helpe, to gain him meane
And opportunitie.
He ſhall want nothing,
I know my Advocate to a hayre, and what
Will fetch him from his prayers, if he uſe any,
I am honyed with the project: I would have him horn'd
For a moſt precious Beaſt.
But you looſe time;
I am gon, inſtruct you Diego, and you will find him
A ſharpe and ſubtle knave, give him but hints
And he will amplifie: Se all things ready
I'll fetch him with a vengeance.—
If ye faile now,
Wee'll give him over too,
Tuſh he is fleſh'd
And knowes what vaine to ſtrike for his owne credit.
All things are ready.
Then we ſhall have a merry Scene, ne're feare it.

div.stage: Enter Amaranta (with a note) and Moore.

lg.l: Is thy Maſter gone out?
Even now, the Curat fetc'h'd him,
About a ſerious buſineſss it ſeem'd,
For he ſnatch'd up his Cloack, and bruſh'd his hat ſtrait,
Set his Band handſomely, and out he gallop'd.
'Tis wil, 'tis very well, he went out (Egla.)
As luckily, as one would ſay, goe Huſband,
He was call'd by providence: fling this ſhort paper
Into Leandro's Cell, and waken him,
He is monſtrous vexed, and muſty, at my Cheſſe-play;
But this ſhall ſupple him, when he has read it:
Take your owne recreation for two houres,
And hinder nothing.
If I doe, I'll hang for't.
If that you lov'd Aſcanio for himſelfe,
And not your private ends, you rather ſhould
Bleſſe the faire opportunitie, that reſtores him
To his Birth-right, and the Honours he was borne to,
Then grieve at his good Fortune.
Grieve Octavio?
I would reſigne my Eſſence, that he were
As happy as my love could faſhion him,
Though every bleſſing that ſhould fall on him,
Might prove a curſe to me, my ſorrow ſprings
Out of my feare, and doubt he is not ſafe.
I am acquainted with Don Henrique's nature,
And I have heard too much the fiery temper
Of Madam Violante: can you thinke
That ſhe, that almoſt is at war with heaven
For being barren, will with equall eyes
Behold a Son of mine?
His Fathers care,
That for the want of Iſſue, tooke him home,
(Though with the forfeiture of his own fame)
Will looke unto his ſafetie.
Step-mothers
Have many eyes, to find a way to miſchiefe,
Though blind to goodneſſe.
Here comes Don Jamy,
And with him our Aſcanio.
Good youth leave me,
I know thou art forbid my company,
And onely to be ſeene with me, will call on
Thy Fathers anger.
Sir, if that to ſerve you
Could looſe me any thing (as indeed it cannot)
I ſtill would follow you. Alas I was borne
To doe you hurt but not to help my ſelfe,
I was, for ſome particular end, tooke home,
But am caſt off againe.
Is't poſſible?
The Lady, whom my Father calls his wife
Abhors my ſight, is ſick of me, and forc'd him
To turne me out of dores.
By my beſt hopes
I thanke her crueltie, for it comes neere
A saving charitie.
I am onely happy
That yet I can relieve you, 'pray you ſhare
My Father's wondrous kind, and promiſes
That I ſhould be ſupplide: but sure the Lady
Is a malitious woman, and I feare
Meanes me no good.
I am turn'd a ſtone with wonder,
And know not what to thinke.
From my Lady,
Your private eare and this—
New Miracles?
She sayes, if you dare make your ſelfe a Fortune,
She will propoſe the meanes; My Lord Don Henrique
Is now from home and she alone expects you,
If you dare truſt her so, if not deſpaire of
A ſecond offer,
Though there were an Ambuſh
Layd for my life, I,ll on and ſound this ſecret,
Retire thee (my Aſcanio) with thy Mother:
But ſtir not forth, ſome great deſigne's on foot,
Fall what can fall, if e're the Sun be ſet,
I ſee you not give me dead.
We will expect you,
And thoſe bleſs'd Angels, that love goodneſſe, guard you.
Is't poſſible he should be rich?
Moſt poſſible,
He hath bin long, though he has but little gettings,
Drawing together Sir.
Accounted a poore Sexton,
Honeſt poore Diego,
I aſſure ye, a cloſe Fellow,
Both cloſe, and ſcraping, and that fills the bags, Sir,
A notable good Fellow too?
Sometimes, Sir, Diego ready in Bed, wine, cup.
When he hop'd to drink a man into a ſurfeit,
That he might gaine by his Grave.
So many thouſands?
Heaven knowes what.
'Tis ſtrange,
,Tis very ſtrange; but we ſee by endeavour,
And honeſt labour—
Milo by continuance
Grew from a ſilly Calfe (with your worſhips reverence)
To carry a Bull from a penny, to a pound, Sir,
And from a pound, to many: 'tis the progreſſe.
Ye say true, but he lov'd to feed well alſo,
And that me-thinks—
From another mans Trencher, Sir,
And there he found it ſeaſon'd with ſmall charge:
There he would play the Tyrant, and would devoure ye
More then the Graves he made at home he liv'd
Like a Camelion, ſuckt th'Ayre of miſery, Table out Stan-
And grew fat by th'Brewis of an Eg-shel, diſh paper, ſtools.
Would smell a Cooks ſhop, and goe home and ſurfeit,
And be a moneth in faſting out that Fever.
(ye?

Theſe are very good Symptomes: do's he lye so ſick, ſay
(ye?

Oh, very
good Lady,ick.
And choſen me Executor?
Onely one Worſhip.
No hope of his amendment?
None, that we find.
He hath no kinſmen neither?
'Truth, very few.
His mind will be the quieter,
What Doctors has he?
There's none sir, he believes in.
They are but needleſſe things, in such exteremities.
Who drawes the good-man's will?
Marry that doe I, Sir.
And to my griefe.
Griefe will doe little now, Sir,
Draw it to your comfort, Friend, and as I counſell ye,
An honeſt man, but ſuch men live not alwayes
Who are about him?
Many now he is paſſing,
That would pretend to his love, yes, and some gentlemen
That would faine counſell him, and be of his kindred;
Rich men can want no heires, Sir.
They doe ill,
Indeed they doe, to trouble him: very ill, Sir,
But we ſhall take a care.

div.stage: Enter Diego (in a bed) Millanes, Arſenio, and Pariſhioners.

lg.l: Will ye come neare, Sir,
'Pray ye bring him out; Now ye may ſee in what ſtate:
Give him freſh ayre.
I am sorry Neighbour Diego,
To find ye in ſo weake a ſtate.
Ye are welcome,
But I am fleeting, Sir.
Me-thinkes he looks well,
His colour freſh, and ſtrong, his eyes are chearfull.
A glimmering before death 'tis nothing els, Sir,
Do you see how he fumbles with the ſheet? do ye note that
My learned Sir 'pray ye ſit: I am bold to ſend for ye,
To take care of what I leave.
Doe you heare that?
Play the knave finely.
So I will, I warrant ye,
And carefully.
'Pray ye doe not trouble him,
You ſee he's weake and has a wandring fancie.
My honeſt Neighbours, weep not, I muſt leave ye,
I cannot alwayes beare ye company,
VVe muſt drop ſtill there is no remedie:
'Pray ye Maſter Curat, will ye write my Teſtament,
And write it largely it may be remembered
And be witneſſe to my Legacies good Gentlemen;
Your worſhip I doe make my full Executor,
You are a man of wit and underſtanding:
Give me a cup of wine to raiſe my Spirits,
For I speake low: I would before theſe Neighbours
Have ye to ſweare (Sir) that you will ſee it executed,
And what I give, let equally be rendered
For my ſoules health.
I vow it truly, Neighbours,
Let not that trouble ye before all theſe
Once more I give my Oath.
Then ſet me higher,
And pray ye come neare me all.
VVe are ready for ye.
Now spur the Aſſe, and get our friend time.
Firſt then,
After I have given my Body to the wormes
(For they muſt be ſerv'd firſt, they are ſeldome cozen'd)
Remember your Pariſh, Neighbour.
You speake truly,
I doe remember it, a lewd vile Pariſh,
And pray it may be mended: To the Poore of it,
(VVhich is to all the Pariſh) I give nothing,
For nothing, unto nothing, is moſt naturall,
Yet leave as much ſpace, as will build a Hoſpitall,
Their children may pray for me.
What doe you give to it?
Set downe two thouſand Duckets,
'Tis a good gift,
And will be long remembered.
To your worſhip,
(Becauſe you muſt take paines to ſee all finiſh'd)
I give two thouſand more, it may be three, Sir,
A poore gratuitie for your paines-taking.
Theſe are large ſummes;
Nothing to him that has 'em.
To my old Maſter Vicar I give five hundred,
(Five hundred, and five hundred, are too few Sir)
But there be more to ſerve.
This fellow coynes ſure.

Give me ſome more drink. Pray ye buy Books, buy
Books,
You have a learned head ſtuffe it with Libraries,
And underſtand 'em, when you have done, 'tis Juſtice,
Run not the Pariſh mad with Controverſies,
Nor preach not Abſtinence to longing women,
'Twill budge the bottoms of their conſciences:
I would give the Church new Organs, but I prophecie

The Church-wardens would quickly pipe'em out o'the'Pa
riſh,-
Two hundred Duckets more to mend the chancel,
And to paint true Orthographie, as many,
They write Sunt with a C which is abominable,
'Pray you ſet that downe, to poore Maidens marriages.
I that's wel thought of, what's your wil in that point?
A meritorious thing.
No end of this will?
I give per annum two hundred ells of Lockram,
That there be no ſtrait dealings in their Linnens,
But the Sayles cut according to their Burthens;
To all Bell-Ringers, I bequeath new Ropes,
And let them uſe 'em at their owne diſcretions.
You may remember us.
I doe, good Gentlemen,
And I bequeath ye both good carefull Surgeons
A Legacy, you have need of, more then money,
I know you want good Diets and good Lotions,
And in your pleaſures good take heed.
He raves now.
But 'twill be quickly off,
I doe bequeath ye
Commodities of pins: browne papers: pack-threds,
Roſt proke, & puddings: Ginger-bread, & Jewes-trumps;
Of penny Pipes, and mouldy Pepper: take 'em,
Take 'em even where you pleaſe and be cozen'd with 'em,
I ſhould bequeath ye Executions alſo,
But thoſe I'll leave to th'Law.
Now he growes temperate.
You will give no more?
I am loth to give more from ye,
Becauſe I know you will have a care to execute
Onely, to pious uſes, Sir, a little.
If he be worth all theſe, I am made for ever,
I give to fatall Dames, that ſpin mens threds out,
And poore diſtreſſed Damſells, that are militant
As members of our owne Afflictions,
A hundred Crowns to buy warm tubbs to worke in,
I give five hundred pounds to buy a Church-yard,
A ſpacious Church-yard, to lay Theeves and knaves in,
Rich men, and honeſt men, take all the roome up.
Are ye not weary?
Never of well-doing.
Theſe are mad Legacies.
They were got as madly;
My Sheep, and Oxen, and my moveables,
My Plate, and Jewells, and five hundred Acres;
I have no heires.
This cannot be, 'tis Monſtrous.
Three Ships at Sea too.
You have made me full Executor.
Full, full, and totall, would I had more to give ye
But theſe may ſerve an honeſt mind.
Ye ſay true,
A very honeſt mind, and make it rich too;
Rich, wondrous rich, but where ſhall I raiſe theſe monys,
About your houſe? I ſee no ſuch great promiſes;
Where ſhall I find theſe ſummes?
Even where you pleaſe Sir,
You are wiſe and provident, and know buſineſſe
Ev'n raiſe 'em where you ſhal think good, I am reaſonable
Thinke good? will that raiſe thouſands?
What doe you make me?
You have ſworn to see it done, that's all my comfort.
Where I pleaſe? this is pack'd ſure to diſgrace me.
You are juſt, and honeſt, and I know you will doe it,
Ev'n where you pleaſe, for you know where the wealth is.
I am abuſed, betrayed, I am laugh'd at, ſcorn'd,
Baffel'd, and boared, it ſeemes.
No, no, ye are fooled.
Moſt finely fooled, and handſomely, and neatly,
Such cunning Maſters muſt be fooled ſometimes, Sir,
And have their worſhips noſes wiped, 'tis healthfull,
We are but quit: you foole us of our moneys
In every Cauſe, in every Quiddit wipe us.

Ha, ha, ha, ha, some more drink, for my heart, Gentle
men
This merry Lawyer—ha,ha,ha,ha, this Scholler—
I thinke this fitt will cure me: this Executor—
I ſhall laugh out my Lungs.
This is deriſion above ſufferance, villany
Plotted, and ſet againſt me.
Faith 'tis knavery,
In troth I muſt confeſſe, thou art fooled indeed, Lawyer.
Did you thinke, had this man been rich—
'Tis well, Sir.
He would have choſen ſuch a Wolfe, a Cancker,
A Maggot-pate, to be his whole Executor.
A Lawyer, that entangles all mens honeſties,
And lives like a Spider in a Cobweb lurking,
And catching at all Flies, that paſſe his pitt-falls?
Puts powder to all States, to make 'em caper?
Would he truſt you?
Doe you deſerve? I find, Gentlemen,
This Cataplaſme of a well cozen'd Lawyer
Laid to my ſtomach lenifies my Fever,
Me-thinkes I could eat now and walke a little.
I am aſham'd to feele how flat I am cheated,
How groſſely, and malitiouſly made a May-game,
A damned Trick; my wife, my wife, some Raſcall:
My credit, and my wife, some luſtfull villaine,
Some Bawd, some Rogue,
Some craftie Foole has found ye:
This 'tis Sir, to teach ye to be too buſie,
To covet all the gaines, and all the rumours.
To have a ſtirring oare, in all mens actions.
We did this, but to vex your fine officiouſneſſe.

Good yeild ye and go'd thank ye: I am fooled, gen
(tlemen;-
The Lawyer is an Aſſe, I doe confeſſe it,
A weak dull shallow Aſſe: good even to your worſhips:
Vicar, remember Vicar, Raſcall remember,
Thou notable rich Raſcall.
I doe remember, Sir,
'Pray ye ſtay a little, I have ev'n two Legacies
To make your mouth up, sir.
Remember Varletts,

Quake & remember, Rouges; I have brine for your But
tocks. Ex.
Oh how he frets, and fumes now like a dunghill.
His gall containes fine ſtuffe now to make poyſons,
Rare damned ſtuffe.
Let's after him, and ſtill vex him,
And take my Friend off: by this time he has proſper'd,
He cannot looſe this deere time: 'tis impoſſible.
Well Diego, thou haſt done.
Haſt done it daintily.
And ſhalt be as well paid, Boy—
Goe, let's crucifie him.
I have told ye all my story, and how deſperately.
I doe believe: let's walke on, time is pretious,
Not to be ſpent in words, here no more wooing,
The open Ayre's an enemy to Lovers, Pewter ready
Doe as I tell ye. for noyſe.
I'll doe any thing,
I am ſo over-joy'd, I'll fly to ſerve ye.
Take your joy moderately, as it is miniſtred,
And as the cauſe invites: that man's a foole
That at the sight o'th'Bond, dances and leapes,
Then is the true joy, when the money comes.
You cannot now deny me.
Nay, you know not,
Women have crotchets, and ſtrange fits.
You ſhall not.
Hold ye to that and ſweare it confidently,
Then I ſhall make a ſcruple to deny ye:
'Pray ye let's ſtep in, and ſee a friend of mine,
The weather's ſharp: we'll ſtay but halfe an houre,
We may be miſs'd els: a private fine houſe 'tis, Sir,
And we may find many good welcomes.
Doe Lady,
Doe happy Lady.
All your mind's of doing,
You muſt be modeſter.
I will be any thing.—
Open the dores, and give me roome to chafe in
Mine owne romme, and my liberty: why Maid there,
lg.note: lo: Ar: Mill: Diego be ready
lg.l: Open, I ſay, and doe not anger me,
I am ſubject to much fury: when ye diſh-clout?
When doe ye come? a ſleepe, ye lazie hell-hound?
Nothing intended, but your eaſe, and eating?
No body here? why wife, why wife? why jewell?
No tongue to anſwer me? 'pree'thee (good Pupill)
Diſpence a little with thy careful ſtudy,
And ſtep to th' doore, and let me in; nor he neither?
Ha! not at's ſtudy? nor aſleepe? nor no-body?
I'll make ye heare: the houſe of Ignorance,
No ſound inhabitants here: I have a key yet
That commands all: I feare I am metamorphiz'd.
He keepes his fury ſtill, and may doe miſchiefe.
He ſhalbe hang'd firſt, we'll be ſticklers there, boyes
The hundred thouſand Dreams now, that poſſes him
Of jealouſie, and of revenge, and frailtie
Of drawing Bills againſt us, and Petitions.
And caſting what his credit shall recover.
Let him caſt till his Maw came up, we care not.
You ſhall be ſtill ſecured.
We'll pay him home then;
Hark what a noyſe he keeps within?
Certaine
H'as ſet his Chimneys o' fire, or the divell roars there.
The Codixes o'th' Law are broke looſe,
He's fighting ſure,
I'll tell ye that immediatly—.
Or doing ſome ſtrange out-rage on himſelfe.
Hang him, he dares not be ſo valiant.
There's no body at home and he chaſes like a Lyon,
And ſtinkes withall.
No body?
Not a creature,
Nothing within, but he and his Law-tempeſt,
The Ladles, diſhes, kettles, how they fly all?
And how the Glaſſes through the Roomes?
My friends ſure
Has got her out, and now he has made an end on't.
See where the Sea comes? how it foams & bruſſels?
The great Leviathan o'th' Law, how it tumbles?
Made every way an Aſſe? abus'd on all ſides?
And from all quarters. people come to laugh at me?
Riſe like a Comet, to be wonder'd at?
A horrid Comet, for Boyes tongues, and Ballads?
I will run from my wits.
Doe, doe (good Lawyer)
And from thy money too, then thou wilt be quiet.
Here ſhe comes home: now mark the ſalutations;
How like an Aſſe my friend goes?
She has pull'd his eares downe.
Now, what ſweet voyage? to what Garden, Lady?
Or to what Coſens houſe?
Is this my welcome?
I cannot goe to Church, but thus I am ſcandall'd,
Uſe no devotion for my soule, but Gentlemen—
To Church?
Yes, and ye keep ſweet youths to wait upon me,
Sweet bred-up youths, to be a credit to me.
There's your delight againe, pray take him to ye,
He never comes neare me more to debaſe me.

How's this? how's this? good wife, how has he wrongd
ye?
I am faine to drive him like a ſheep before me,
I bluſh to thinke how people fleere, and ſcorn'd me,
Others have handſome men, that know behaviour,
Place, and obſervance: this ſilly thing knowes nothing,
Cannot tell ten; Let every Raſcall juſtle me,
And ſtill I puſh'd him on, as he had bin comming.
Ha! did ye puſh him on? is he ſo ſtupid?
When others were attentive to the Prieſt,
Good devout Gentleman, then fell he faſt
Faſt, ſound aſleep: then firſt began the Bag-pipes
The ſeverall ſtops on's noſe, made a rare muſick,
A rare and lowd, and thoſe plaid many an Antheme
Put out of that, he fell ſtrait into dreaming.
As cunning as ſhe is ſweet; I like this carriage.
What did he then?
Why then he talked in his Sleep too,
Nay, I'll divulge your morall vertues (ſheeps-face)
And talk'd aloude, that every eare was fixt to him:
Did not I ſuffer (doe you thinke) in this time?
Talk of your bawling Law, of appellations
Of Declarations, and Excommunications:
Warrants, the Executions: and ſuch divells

That drove all the Gentlemen out o'th'Church, by hur
ryes
With execrable oaths, they would never come there again
Thus am I ſerv'd, and man'd.
I pray ye forgive me,
I muſt confeſſe I am not fit to wait upon ye:
Alas, I was brought up—
To be an Aſſe,
A Lawyers Aſſe, to carry Bookes, and Buckrams.
But what did you at Church?
At Church, did ye aſke her?
Doe you heare gentlemen, doe you mark the queſtion?
Becauſe you are halfe an heretique your ſelfe, Sir,
Would ye breed her too? this ſhall to the Inquiſition,
A pious Gentlewoman, reprov'd for praying?
I'll ſee this filed, and you ſhall heare further, Sir.
Ye have an ill heart.
It ſhall be found out Gentlemen,
There be thoſe youths will ſearch it.
You are warme Signiour,
But a Faggot will warme ye better: we are witneſſes.
Enough to hang him, doe not doubt.
Nay certaine,
I doe beleeve has rather no Religion.
(Church, sir?

That muſt be knowne too, becauſe ſhee goes to
(Church sir?
O monſtrum informe ingens!
Let him goe on, ſir,
His wealth will build a Nunnery, a faire one,
And this good Lady, when he is hang'd, and rotten,
May there be Abbeſſe.
You are cozend, honeſt Gentlemen,
I doe not forbid the uſe, but the forme, marke me.
Forme? what doe ye make of Forme?
They will undoe me,
Sweare, as I oft have done, and ſo betray me;
I muſt make faire way, and hereafter, Wife,
You are welcome home, & henceforth take your pleaſure,
Goe, when ye ſhall thinke fit, I will not hinder ye,
My eyes are open now, and I ſee my e[]rour,
My ſhame, as great as that, but I muſt hide it.
The whole conveyance now I ſmell, but Baſta,
Another time muſt ſerve: you ſee us friends, now
Heartily friends, and no more chiding (gentlemen)
I have bin too fooliſh, I confeſſe, no more words,
No more (ſweet wife.)
You know my eaſie nature
Goe get ye in: you ſee ſhe has bin angry:
Forebeare her fight a while and time will pacify.
And learne to be more bold.
I would I could,
I will doe all I am able.
Doe Leandro.
We will not part, but friends of all hands.
Well ſaid,
Now ye are reaſonable, we can looke on ye,
Ye have ierckt me: but for all that I forgive ye
Forgive ye hartily, and doe invite ye
Tomorrow to a Breakfaſt, I make but ſeldome
But now we will be merry.
Now ye are friendly,
Your doggednes and nigardize flung from ye,
And now we will come to ye
Give me your hands, all;
You shall be wellcome hartily.
We will be,
For wee'll eate hard
The harder, the more wellcome,
And till the morning farewell; I have buſines.
Farewell good bountiful Bartolus 'tis a brave wench
A ſudaine witty Theif, and worth all ſervice:
Goe wee'll all goe, and crucifie the Lawyer,
I'll clap foure tire of teeth into my mouth more
But I will grind his ſubſtance.
Well Leandro,
Thou haſt had a ſtrange voyage, but I hope
Thou rid'st now in ſafe harbour,
Lets goe drinke, Friends,
And laugh alou'd at all our merry may-games
A match, a match 'twill whet our ſtomachs better.
